dt: {bc}disgusting or distasteful by reason of excess

dt.t: Her coyness grows {wi}cloying{/wi} after a while …

shortdef: disgusting or distasteful by reason of excess; also : excessively sweet or sentimental

dt: {bc}to supply with an unwanted or distasteful excess usually of something originally pleasing

dt.t: … Cordelia has been {wi}cloyed{/wi} by her sisters' excessive protestations of affection …

dt: {bc}to be or become insipid or distasteful usually through an excess of an originally pleasurable quality (such as sweetness)

dt.t: … curious how the lemon keeps its bite when the sweet flavours have begun to {wi}cloy{/wi}, and the crispness has departed.

pt: {sc}satiate{/sc} {sc}sate{/sc} {sc}surfeit{/sc} {sc}cloy{/sc} {sc}pall{/sc} {sc}glut{/sc} {sc}gorge{/sc} mean to fill to repletion. {sc}satiate{/sc} and {sc}sate{/sc} may sometimes imply only complete satisfaction but more often suggest repletion that has destroyed interest or desire.

pt.t: years of globe-trotting had {it}satiated{/it} their interest in travel

pt: {sc}cloy{/sc} stresses the disgust or boredom resulting from such surfeiting.

pt.t: sentimental pictures that {it}cloy{/it} after a while

pt: {sc}pall{/sc} emphasizes the loss of ability to stimulate interest or appetite.

pt.t: a life of leisure eventually begins to {it}pall{/it}

pt: {sc}glut{/sc} implies excess in feeding or supplying.
{sc}gorge{/sc} suggests glutting to the point of bursting or choking.

et: Middle English, to hinder, lame, alteration of {it}acloyen{/it} to harm, maim, modification of Anglo-French {it}encloer{/it} to nail, prick a horse with a nail in shoeing, from Medieval Latin {it}inclavare{/it}, from Latin {it}in{/it} + {it}clavus{/it} nail
shortdef: to supply with an unwanted or distasteful excess usually of something originally pleasing
to be or become insipid or distasteful usually through an excess of an originally pleasurable quality (such as sweetness)
